title: EastEnders star Katie Jarvis responds to 'job shaming' for B&M work
text:
EastEnders star Katie Jarvis has responded to being job-shamed for daring to support her two children with a retail security job, revealing that she felt embarrassed by the ‘nasty’ approach by a tabloid which made it their front page splash on Sunday.

The star, who played Hayley Slater in the soap and is also known for a leading role in the film Fish Tank, currently works at B&M Bargains and in the wake of the tabloid story, actors took to Twitter to support her and list all of the jobs that they do in between roles to keep food on the table.

Unlike what many people might think, appearing on television for a few months doesn’t mean a person is set up for life and it’s pretty expected in the industry to work other jobs – and many actors made the point that it’s the main way of building life experience which can then be brought to roles.

Speaking on the Victoria Derbyshire Show, Katie said: ‘I woke up really embarrassed and made to feel ashamed when I saw the story. I have done my best over my career to keep my private life as private as possible so always stayed away from celebrity events. So to see myself on the front page while with my kids just for having a job in between acting jobs…

‘All actors go through it, I have had loads of other jobs. I was doing the doughnuts when I did Fish Tank. That’s the life of an actor – I like to be busy and learn new things. I’ve been a waitress, worked for a credit card company and everything.’

And she also wanted to make the point that her colleagues at the B&M Bargains store she works at really put in the hours and work as hard as any actor. She said: ‘The people I work with are amazing and work hard for their money. As long as you’re working, that’s all that matters, no-one should be shamed for what they do.

‘The way the story was portrayed wasn’t very nice. It was quite nasty – to be made to feel degraded is wrong. Security guards put themselves at risk, there’s a lot goes into it – I joined my sister there as she does the same job. I feel I need to stand up for working class people.’

While the initial feeling Katie got was shock and dismay, she was later made aware of the outpouring of support from celebrities from the soap, television, film and showbiz industries – and she admitted to being bowled over by the kind words.

She smiled: ‘I am overwhelmed by it, I didn’t realise. I’m not on Twitter so didn’t see any of it. It’s kept me away from the bad stuff but to hear that was amazing – I am so glad to have their support.’
